title: Master Solvers' Club
excerpt: Eight bidding problems with expert panel responses and scoring.

data.text:
**The BRIDGE WORLD**

Yes, they do have plenty of room.

GERALD CARAVELLI: "Four diamonds. I'll bid as far as I'm willing to go. If East is declarer, I'm on lead; if West declares a slam, I can double (and hope)."

HENRY BETHE: "Four diamonds. Looks about right on loser count."

Maybe at a worse vulnerability.

MARTIN ROSENBERGY: "Two diamonds. Michaels. ROSENBERGY: "Two diamonds. Keep it low, maybe I'll get a chance to bid three notrump, which will depict my hold-ing fairly well. I have had bad experiences preempting with hands such as this. (Of course, I've also had bad experiences when my opponents bid slam.)

ATHUR ROBINSON: "c. Four clubs. I assume that too many opponents bid too much.

Richmond partners may think I should start with three clubs. In "Weak Twos in Diamonds", my article in the March issue, I refer to one level holds and double jumps as strong (preemptively).

We shouldn't be able to make four clubs. Maybe if I bid four hearts they would bid four spades, so I'm going to slam their suit. They're very unlikely to slam, and if they do, I expect to be on lead (if we defend), and they don't rate to make grand slam.

It's more likely that RHO will be de-clarer, so that you will be on lead. Are you contemplating fourth from your longest and strongest?

BOB ROWELL: "Four diamonds. Preempts would be a good save, unless part-ner to raise with a fit, but leaves East-West room to have an accident."

While the behavioral pot simmered through the late '50s and early '60s, in other dimensions tournaments kept cooking in more or less the usual way. Individual events. (By far the most successful casual stars in this universe were the ones with the most plated personalities, such as B. Jay Becker and Norman Kay.) However, in 1957, when Edgar came the McKenney Trophy with what was then considered an astronomical masterpoint total (chicken feed in today), the was regarded as a premier event. And the contest for winning the most master-points in a year (then called the McKenney; now named after Barry Crane) was regarded as significant; indeed the resulting scramble to accumulate points apparently tainted the game of bridge for the U.S. In the closed Room, West doubled five clubs, the inevitable terminal auction played a step of the scramble. **Problem H**

Matchips: none vul. You, South, hold:

SOUTH   WEST    NORTH   EAST
1NT     2♦      3NT     (All Pass)

East leads the heart eight out of turn. Do you (a) accept the lead and see dummy before you play to trick one? (b) forbid West from leading a heart for as long as he is on lead and see dummy? (c) require West to lead a heart (with no further penalty)? (d) prohibit West from leading a heart for as long as he is on lead (with no further penalty)? (e) make the heart eight at first legal opportunity?

Action      Score   Votes
c           100     17
e           70      10
b           30      10
a           20      1
d           20      1
f           40      1

Six spades by South.     Lead: Club queen

A superior plat is to duck a trump at trick one, you are in trouble. If you switch to hearts, the defender with four trumps may be able to ruff in and lead a trump, leaving you a trick short. Alternatively, if you take two club ruffs after the sec-ond trump you will still face a diamond guess; the long-trump defender may have another club, should you inmay have another club, should you instead try hearts, the third round may be ruffled, cutting you off from the pitch for your diamond loser.
